instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1286: What is A1286? A1286 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2009 , Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2255, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2330, 820-2532, 820-2523, 820-2533, 820-2850, 820-2915, 820-3330..
definitions.A1278: What is A1278? A1278 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook or Macbook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2254, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2327, 820-2530, 820-2879, 820-2936, 820-3115..

threads.title: Old <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - Broken memory clip
threads.message: What seemed like a simple repair just became a major frustration: one of the memory retention clips broke off. The upper memory slot now won't hold it's memory in place. Any suggestions on how to properly repair this?

threads.title: Old <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - Broken memory clip
Old <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - Broken memory clip
threads.message:
[QUOTE="aprendiz, post: 31792"]max out the working slot....[/QUOTE]

I'm sure this is the best option when something is wrong with the electrical connections of the slot, but this is a simple mechanical failure. It will be fixed, I was hoping for someone with a good suggestion on how :)

threads.title: Old <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - Broken memory clip
threads.message: You asked for any solutions...there is no solution without replacing the RAM slots/banks (have fun). You can melt another clip in place, but it won't be strong enough to withstand being re-stressed in the future. The best "solution" you're after will be a unit-level solution (i.e. you install the board into a unit and then essentially fix the RAM in place someway, however you choose), NOT a board-level solution. Period. Don't waste your time; max out working slot, move on.

threads.title: Old <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - Broken memory clip
threads.message: Tape it in there. Or glue, or whatever. Get creative.
